Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Power-Performance Tradeoffs for Mobile Devices in Next Generation WiFi Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the tremendous growth in smartphones and other mobile devices, and the increasingly complex applications they run, the impact of the energy consumption is felt by every user. Smartphone batteries need to be charged too often or the devices are run in modes that limit their capabilities, to save energy. A major fraction of the energy consumption in smartphones comes from the WiFi radio. The next generation WiFi radios include a rich set of features offering increased bit rates, longer range, and more reliable coverage. However, these benefits often come at the cost of significantly higher power consumption. Consequently, smartphone manufacturers often restrict the features available to the users, thus trading performance for power savings. Also, the increasing demand for computational features such as multimedia in mobile devices has led to the use of complex computational hardware and peripherals for graphics and memory with higher contribution to the overall energy consumption. Hence, there is a need to develop a holistic approach to power analysis that considers both the communication and the computational paradigms, and novel protocols that efficiently utilize the battery power without compromising performance, which this projects aims to achieve. This work can have a lasting impact on better energy utilization in the mobile environment.

This project seeks to develop models that capture the power-performance tradeoffs in WiFi-capable mobile devices and the impact of different features of the next generation WiFi standards on these tradeoffs. The models are to be developed based on extensive measurement studies using different mobile devices in a variety of scenarios. Further, it seeks to build realistic power models that consider diverse components of the system and their interactions, beyond just the CPU, as well as models for power-performance tradeoffs at the system level. Power analysis of the computational elements and peripherals will be developed, with considerations to varying factors that affect the power consumption, such as the applications, environment, and usage profile, through power modeling and measurements. The results will then be integrated with the WiFi models resulting in a holistic power model and profile. The developed models will guide the design of novel power management, rate adaptation, and WLAN management protocols that will allow mobile devices to realize more of their potential, while minimizing the power consumption and the impact to other WLAN clients. The project will bring increased awareness of energy consumption issues in modern mobile devices through outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This objective of this research was to understand the performance-power tradeoffs of next generation WiFi radios on power-constrained devices, and develop measurement-based models to capture these tradeoffs. A second objective was to perform power analysis at the system and application levels through a thorough power modeling and measurement, and combine it with the WiFi power models in addressing power performance tradeoffs with considerations at multiple levels. The project also considered user adaptable power solutions that fit the needs of individuals. The main project outcomes are as follows:

(i) We conducted extensive measurement studies of WiFi performance and power consumption using smartphones of different generations, equipped with WiFi radios supporting three different IEEE 802.11 standards, namely 802.11n, 802.11ac, and 802.11ad. Our studies have led to a deep understanding of the impact of each of the novel PHY/MAC features introduced by the three standards (MIMO, Frame aggregation, channel bonding, short guard interval in 802.11n and 802.11ac, ultra-wideband channels and beamforming in 802.11ad) on performance and power consumption. For example, we showed that in 802.11n/ac, channel bonding is the most power-hungry feature, followed by MIMO. As another example, our first-ever experimental study of the power consumption of 60 GHz radios showed that, contrary to early skepticism, their energy efficiency is similar to that of legacy WiFi radios, thanks to the Gigabit/sec data rates that help counter-balance the much higher power consumption. Interestingly, a few months ago, Asus launched the first smartphone featuring a 60 GHz radio on the market, essentially confirming our findings.

(ii) We developed new models of the WiFi power consumption in smartphones and modified existing ones, developed for laptop computers and WiFi routers, to accurately reflect the smartphone characteristics. First, we built a set of throughput-based power consumption models for 802.11n and 802.11ac radios that offer different tradeoffs between complexity and accuracy. Second, we revisited the state-of-the-art "cross-factor" model and incorporated the impact of the power-save mode (PSM), significantly improving its accuracy at low data rates, typical of many smartphone applications.

(iii) We showed that, contrary to previous beliefs, today’s smartphones equipped with 60 GHz radios are capable of handling multi-Gigabit/sec data rates without significant strain on their hardware resources and identified the factors (Linux segmentation offloading, CPU affinity) that make this possible and the contribution of each of them.

(iv) We showed the importance of appropriate power models which consider circuit to system level and address balancing energy consumption and security in mobile devices. We applied the same design principles to context aware models, which also consider user tunable power modeling that adapts to the usage patterns.

(v) In addition to prototyping power aware architectures, we have also considered diverse applications, such as security and machine learning within the mobile environment. In the process, we considered the energy consumption as a combination of approaches at the architectural level, memory systems, and the application layer.

(vi) We showed that background operations and sync applications on smartphones, which run independently of the available mobile device resources and the network conditions, can lead to significant resource and energy consumption. Our findings motivated the design of user-profile based resource budgeting in mobile devices.

(vii) As the range of smartphone applications have grown significantly with more high performance processor systems and system on chips with additional custom functional units, such as for graphics, multimedia, AI and signal processing applications, accurate function aware and usage specific analysis is more appropriate to reflect realistic system level energy models.

The research has led to multiple publications in top conferences and journals and a best paper award in the ACM mmNets 2019 workshop. We have also made a data set of throughput, power, and energy traces that we used to build our throughput-based power models publicly available. The project has trained a number of PhD, MS, and undergraduate students, including three female PhD students, three female MS students, and one African American undergraduate student, teaching them fundamental skills for system building and evaluation, data collection and analysis, and experimental-based power modeling, and has been integrated into three courses taught by the PI and Co-PI at the University at Buffalo. The practical nature of the project allowed PhD students to secure successful internships in top industrial research labs and initiated collaborations between the PI and researchers from Technicolor and HP Labs.
